fields.description:
This failure was seen in the following bfebs test upon run instance. Looked at this with Ken and Zach who can provide more info as to the failure. 
Thanks,
-Matt


http://qa-server/euca-qa/display_test.php?testname=CI-3.2-pkg-centos6-00&uid=1069

fields.summary: BFEBS run instance failure. RollbackException: Error while committing the transaction
fields.environment:
machine00	CENTOS	6.3	64	REPO	[UI CC00 CLC SC00 WS]
machine01	CENTOS	6.3	64	REPO	[NC00]
SAN_PROVIDER=NO-SAN

comments.body: The commit exception is hit when doing a lookup of the VmVolumeAttachment entity against the Vm that is being updated with the returned remoteDevice string from the SC during volume attachment.

Commit: 046820942c885c8d6c49bfd5f2f3758b18fc3671 [0468209]
Parents: 35c6cb0810
Author: chris grzegorczyk <grze@eucalyptus.com>
Date: November 30, 2012 10:59:40 AM PST
Commit Date: November 30, 2012 11:02:21 AM PST

Fixes EUCA-4271 Increase default timeout values


Verified through BFEBS testing.

Looks like this failed in the same manner post commit a4c4c95b966a7504a94c66ce6b470854b73b661e
See BFEBS failure in test:
http://qa-server/euca-qa/display_test.php?testname=CI-3.2-pkg-centos6-00&uid=1072
Thanks,
-M

...and 1 more failure:

http://qa-server/euca-qa/display_test.php?testname=CI-3.2-src-centos6-00&uid=1054

Pretty consistent in this test sequence. 
Thanks,
-M

Could be running out of addresses. In the CLC logs there are ERRORs about unallocating addresses and I am seeing this in the cc log for the failed fbebs instance:
{code}
2012-11-30 19:28:13  INFO 000003948 doRunInstances           | invoked
2012-11-30 19:28:13 DEBUG 000003948 doRunInstances           | params: userId=7NLRDVZFASVBOUSB5YE0J, emiId=UNSET, kernelId=UNSET, ramdiskId=UNSET, emiURL=UNSET, kernelURL=UNSET, ramdiskURL=UNSET, instIdsLen=1, netNamesLen=1, macAddrsLen=1, networkIndexListLen=1, minCount=1, maxCount=1, accountId=740508489339, ownerId=7NLRDVZFASVBOUSB5YE0J, reservationId=r-56CB40C1, keyName=ssh-rsa  740508489339@eucalyptus.bfebskey856, vlan=-1, userData=, launchIndex=0, platform=linux, targetNode=UNSET
2012-11-30 19:28:13 DEBUG 000003948 doRunInstances           | running instance i-6A7B44CB
2012-11-30 19:28:13 ERROR 000003948 param_check              | incorrect input parameters to function vnetAddHost
2012-11-30 19:28:13 DEBUG 000003948 doRunInstances           | assigning MAC/IP: d0:0d:6A:7B:44:CB/0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0/27
2012-11-30 19:28:13 ERROR 000003948 doRunInstances           | could not find/initialize any free network address, failing doRunInstances()
2012-11-30 19:28:13 DEBUG 000003948 doRunInstances           | done.
2012-11-30 19:28:13 ERROR 000003948 doRunInstances           | unable to run input instance
2012-11-30 19:28:13ERROR: doRunInstances() failed 1
{code}
And on the CLC:
{code}
Fri Nov 30 19:28:12 2012 ERROR [ClusterAllocator:Eucalyptus.cluster:ClusterConfiguration:arn:euca:eucalyptus:PARTI00:cluster:CC_74/.class java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker#234] [com.eucalyptus.cloud.run.ClusterAllocator.makeVmTypeInfo(ClusterAllocator.java):334] javax.persistence.RollbackException: Error while committing the transaction
{code}

http://10.1.1.210/test_space/GA-base-multistorage-centos6-3.2/1014/bfebs_test_No_000/artifacts/
related to 4237, pending checkin from Zach.

I have several small improvements to the SC and CLC pending and undergoing testing currently.

One is a change to bump the CLC network timeout to 35min from 30min such that it is just longer than the EBS timeout so that the network and volume aren't timing out simultaneously and triggering updates concurrently for the same instance.

The other fixes are removing the old BlockStorageStatistics code from the SC (it has been unused for a while) since it is causing periodic DB exceptions and is useless code at this point. I also added some changes to be sure the SC keeps track of its state better if an operation does fail. It now will commit the state it does have to the DB rather than rolling-back and losing track of resources.

The fix is invasive and risky for 3.2.0.  The fix in the network management for the CLC and instance cleanup. 
We're seeing this in our testing, roughly 15/1000 times.  

Zach will provide some additional info on this failure and the recovery scenario.  

We will not fix for 3.2.0.

Just confirmed that on the latest code we are seeing some failures but they are very infrequent and the result is that the volume left behind on the instance failure eventually goes from "attached" to "available" according to correct timeouts and is both viewable by the user and deletable by the user. I just successfully cleaned the 14 leftover volumes from the current churn test's 1100 bfebs starts.

So, while an instance failure may occur and the volume may be left behind, it is not orphaned and is able to be deleted by users after the instance state timeouts kick (may be 12 hours or more). This is not a release-critical issue anymore.

More detail for a known-issue writeup and for fixing later.

The failure case is that network resources (primarily vlan tags for the network group) are freed concurrently while a new instance is being constructed in that same group. If the network group is seen to have no more instances then the CC can timeout the vlan tag and then informs the CLC. The CLC frees the resource but if there is a concurrent instance being constructed then it may have already grabbed that vlan tag and upon volume attach the database update fails because the vlan/network tag record doesn't exist. 

The error path for this does not properly detach the volume and then delete it, so the volume stays on the SC in an attached state (awaiting connections from an NC that will never connect because the instance was cancelled). Eventually the vm metadata timeouts clear the state of the volume on the CLC back to available and the volume can be deleted by the user via normal eucalyptus commands.
No longer seeing this failure in long term testing.

Still seeing this in QA runs. Reducing the severity because the following attempts to run the same image succeed and this seems to be a transient failure. This happens a very small % of the time in churn. Maybe <1%, however in QA runs I've seen this as the first 2nd instance ever run on a system, and during a fairly idle period. 

ttp://qa-server.eucalyptus-systems.com/euca-qa/display_test.php?testname=GA-base-multistorage-centos6-3.2&uid=1033&prev_page=http%3A%2F%2Fqa-server.eucalyptus-systems.com%2Feuca-qa%2Fstart_test.php&Refresh=Refresh

Regarding the vlan=-<N> issue, we've discovered the root cause/information about how to detect when this condition occurs.  This issue is present in 3.1.0 - 3.2.0.

When this can occur:

Given a security group S, if there are no instances currently running in security group S, and the user issues a run-instances for one or more instances in sec. group S, there is a chance that one or more instances will fail to run due to a race in the system.  The chance that this will happen will be increased if the time it takes to 'prepare' an instance in the front-end is long as is the case for a BFEBS instance with TGT with the CLC/SC co-located.

What it looks like (how to detect) when it occurs:

To the end-user, the effect of this condition is an instance that stays in 'pending' with '0.0.0.0' for a very long time (longer than other identical instances that have worked in the past).  To the cloud admin, this condition can be detected by looking at the cc.log files and finding a line that shows:


doRunInstances           | invoked: userId=............................................vlan=-1.............................

note that any negative number N in the 'vlan=<N>' field of doRunInstances means that this condition has occurred.

What to do when this occurs:

There is no long-term negative effect of this condition on the system, it will be treated like any other 'instance failed to run' condition, properly.  The user should proceed with terminating the instance, deleting its resulting volume (in the BFEBS case, if the related volume has been left behind), and then re-running the instance.

I have not seen this behavior at this time. I will "Approve fix for Release", if we see no issues during the next GA run.
